sentences.text: כׇּל אוֹתָן שָׁנִים שֶׁהָיוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בַּמִּדְבָּר, הָיוּ עַצְמוֹתָיו שֶׁל יְהוּדָה מְגוּלְגָּלִין בָּאָרוֹן, עַד שֶׁעָמַד מֹשֶׁה וּבִקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים. אָמַר לְפָנָיו: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, מִי גָּרַם לִרְאוּבֵן שֶׁהוֹדָה — יְהוּדָה: ״וְזֹאת לִיהוּדָה״?!
sentences.human_translation: All those years that the Jewish people were in the desert, the bones of Judah, were rolling in the coffin, until Moses arose and asked for compassion on said before Master of the Universe, who served as the impetus for Reuben that he admit Judah, “And this for Judah,”
sentences.llm_translation: All those who have lived for eighty years, who have been Israelites according to the Torah, their deeds are nullified in the world, until that one who has been tested by Moshe and has been tested by the people, has shown mercy. Said to him: What is the measure of the measure, if the measure is to be measured by the measure of the measure, — Torah: "And it shall be, when you have come into the land, that you shall take of the first fruits of the land, the produce of the land, and you shall give unto the Levites, the Levites alone, the Levites and the Levites alone, Levites: "?!

sentences.text: מִיָּד: ״שְׁמַע ה׳ קוֹל יְהוּדָה״, עָל אֵיבְרֵיהּ לְשָׁפָא. וְלָא הֲוָה קָא מְעַיְּילִין לֵיהּ לִמְתִיבְתָּא דִרְקִיעָא, ״וְאֶל עַמּוֹ תְּבִיאֶנּוּ״. וְלָא הֲוָה קָא יָדַע מִשְׁקַל וּמִטְרַח בִּשְׁמַעְתָּא בַּהֲדֵי רַבָּנַן, ״יָדָיו רָב לוֹ״. לָא הֲוָה קָא סָלְקָא לֵיהּ שְׁמַעְתָּא אַלִּיבָּא דְהִילְכְתָא, ״וְעֵזֶר מִצָּרָיו תִּהְיֶה״.
sentences.human_translation: Immediately “Hear, Lord, the voice of Judah” His bones entered sockets [ shafa ], But did not elevate into the heavenly study hall. “And bring him in unto his people” but he did not know to deliberate with the sages. “His hands shall contend for him” he was unable to draw his discussion in accordance with the halakha . “And You shall be a help against his adversaries”
sentences.llm_translation: R. Yehudah said: "The voice of the Lord is the voice of Judah" (Psalm 111:1), to his disciples, to the students of Rav Huna, "to the people, to bring them" (Psalm 111:1). And to the one who knows from the words of the Talmud, "to the people, to bring them" (Psalm 111:1). And to the one who knows from the words of the Sages, "his ways are good" (Proverbs 3:17), "to him are many" (Proverbs 3:17). And to the one who is led astray by the words of the Sages, "to the people, to bring them" (Psalm 111:1), "to be a snare to his people" (Psalm 111:1).

sentences.text: בִּשְׁלָמָא יְהוּדָה דְּאוֹדִי, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלֹא תִּישָּׂרֵף תָּמָר. אֶלָּא רְאוּבֵן, לְמָה לֵיהּ דְּאוֹדִי? וְהָאָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: חֲצִיף עֲלַי דִּמְפָרֵיט חֶטְאֵיהּ? כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִיחַשְׁדוּ אֲחוֹהִי.
sentences.human_translation: Granted, Judah, that he admitted in order that Tamar not be burned But why did Reuben admit But didn’t Rav Sheshet say: I who specifies his sins brazen, in order that his brothers should not be suspected
sentences.llm_translation: In the book of the law of Judah, it is written: "How is it that you have not been careful to follow the commandments?" For Reuben, to what extent is he to be pitied? And the saying of Rav Sheshet: "I am burdened with the weight of his sins, for I have been a witness to his wickedness." For what is the case with him, that he should be pitied? The Talmud text is from the following Tractate: Tractate: Berachot 34b Page: 34b Translation of the text is from the book: Book: Talmud Yerushalmi Edition: Steinsaltz Page: 34b

sentences.text: אִם אָמְרָה ״טְמֵאָה אֲנִי״ וְכוּ׳. שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ כּוֹתְבִין שׁוֹבָר.
sentences.human_translation: If she says: I am defiled, You learn from this that one writes a receipt
sentences.llm_translation: If one says "I am a slave" and the other says "I am free", they are both lying. For your ears have heard the words of the great ones, who have bound the multitude.

sentences.text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, תְּנִי: ״מְקָרַעַת״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: וְהָא ״שׁוֹבֶרֶת״ קָתָנֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: בִּמְקוֹם שֶׁאֵין כּוֹתְבִין כְּתוּבָּה עָסְקִינַן.
sentences.human_translation: Abaye said: Teach She tears Rava said to him: But teaches she writes a receipt. Rather, Rava said: We are dealing with a place in they do not write a marriage contract,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Avyay said: "I have learned that..." Rav Yehuda said to him: "What is this'severance'?! Rabbis! Is it not said in the verse: 'You shall not covet your neighbor's house, nor his slave, nor his ox, nor his donkey, nor anything that is your neighbor's'?" Rav said: "In a place where there is no one to write down the deed, one should not ask to be a witness."

sentences.text: וְאִם אָמְרָה ״טְהוֹרָה אֲנִי״ מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ לְשַׁעֲרֵי מִזְרָח. מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ?!
sentences.human_translation: But if she says: I am pure, they bring her up to the Eastern Gate. they bring her up?
sentences.llm_translation: And if one says "I am the one who is responsible for her" - that is, for the daughter of Rav Yehuda, - is it not to be considered as having brought her to the horns of the devil? text: דְּרַבָּנַן אַדְּרַבָּנַן נָמֵי לָא קַשְׁיָא. הָכָא טַעְמָא מַאי? מִשּׁוּם ״וְנִוַּסְּרוּ כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים״. הָתָם — אֵין לְךָ יִיסּוּר גָּדוֹל מִזֶּה.
וְכִי תֵּימָא לַעֲבֵיד בַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי — אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ, אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ״ — בְּרוֹר לוֹ מִיתָה יָפָה.

לֵימָא דְּרַב נַחְמָן תַּנָּאֵי הִיא? לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא אִית לְהוּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן. וְהָכָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, מָר סָבַר: בִּזְיוֹנֵיהּ עֲדִיף לֵיהּ טְפֵי מִצַּעְרָא דְגוּפֵיהּ, וּמָר סָבַר: צַעְרָא דְגוּפֵיהּ עֲדִיף לֵיהּ טְפֵי מִבִּזְיוֹנֵיהּ.
הָיְתָה מְכוּסָּה לְבָנִים וְכוּ׳. תָּנָא, אִם הָיוּ שְׁחוֹרִים נָאִים לָהּ — מְכַסִּין אוֹתָהּ בְּגָדִים מְכוֹעָרִים.

הָיוּ עָלֶיהָ כְּלֵי זָהָב וְכוּ׳. פְּשִׁיטָא, הַשְׁתָּא נַוּוֹלֵי מְנַוֵּויל לַהּ, הָנֵי מִיבַּעְיָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: בְּהָנֵי אִית לַהּ בִּזָּיוֹן טְפֵי, כִּדְאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: שָׁלִיחַ עַרְטִיל וְסָיֵים מְסָאנֵי. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.

וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵבִיא חֶבֶל וְכוּ׳. בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּי אַבָּא מֵרַב הוּנָא: חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי מַהוּ שֶׁיְּעַכֵּב בְּסוֹטָה? מִשּׁוּם שֶׁלֹּא יִשָּׁמְטוּ בְּגָדֶיהָ מֵעָלֶיהָ הוּא, וּבְצִלְצוֹל קָטָן נָמֵי סַגִּי, אוֹ דִילְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאָמַר מָר ״הִיא חָגְרָה לוֹ בְּצִלְצוֹל, לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מֵבִיא חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי וְקוֹשֵׁר לָהּ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ״ — מְעַכֵּב?
אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנֵיתוּהָ: וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵבִיא חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי וְקוֹשְׁרוֹ לָהּ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִשָּׁמְטוּ בְּגָדֶיהָ מֵעָלֶיהָ.

וְכׇל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ יִרְאֶה וְכוּ׳. הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא. אָמְרַתְּ: כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה, אַלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא גַּבְרֵי וְלָא שְׁנָא נְשֵׁי, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים מוּתָּרוֹת לִרְאוֹתָהּ: נָשִׁים — אִין, אֲנָשִׁים — לָא.
אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: תַּרְגְּמַהּ אֲנָשִׁים. אָמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: וְהָא ״כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה״ קָתָנֵי!

אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: כׇּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה, לָא שְׁנָא גַּבְרֵי וְלָא שְׁנָא נְשֵׁי. וְנָשִׁים חַיָּיבוֹת לִרְאוֹתָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְנִוַּסְּרוּ כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים וְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂינָה כְּזִמַּתְכֶנָה״.

מַתְנִי׳ בְּמִדָּה שֶׁאָדָם מוֹדֵד — בָּהּ מוֹדְדִין לוֹ. הִיא קִשְּׁטָה אֶת עַצְמָהּ לַעֲבֵירָה — הַמָּקוֹם נִוְּולָהּ. הִיא גִּלְּתָה אֶת עַצְמָהּ לַעֲבֵירָה — הַמָּקוֹם גִּלָּה עָלֶיהָ. בַּיָּרֵךְ הִתְחִילָּה בַּעֲבֵירָה תְּחִילָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ הַבֶּטֶן — לְפִיכָךְ תִּלְקֶה הַיָּרֵךְ תְּחִילָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ הַבֶּטֶן, וּשְׁאָר כָּל הַגּוּף לֹא פָּלַט.
גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: אַף עַל גַּב דְּמִדָּה בְּטֵילָה, בַּמִּדָּה לֹא בָּטֵיל.

דְּאָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, וְכֵן תָּנֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא: מִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁבָּטְלָה סַנְהֶדְרִי — אַרְבַּע מִיתוֹת לֹא בָּטְלוּ. וְהָא בָּטְלוּ?! אֶלָּא: דִּין אַרְבַּע מִיתוֹת לֹא בָּטְלוּ.

מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב סְקִילָה — אוֹ נוֹפֵל מִן הַגָּג, אוֹ חַיָּה דּוֹרַסְתּוֹ. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב שְׂרֵיפָה — אוֹ נוֹפֵל בִּדְלֵיקָה, אוֹ נָחָשׁ מַכִּישׁוֹ. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב הֲרִיגָה — אוֹ נִמְסָר לַמַּלְכוּת, אוֹ לִיסְטִין בָּאִין עָלָיו. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב חֲנִיקָה — אוֹ טוֹבֵעַ בַּנָּהָר, אוֹ מֵת בִּסְרוֹנְכֵי.
תַּנְיָא, הָיָה רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁבְּמִדָּה שֶׁאָדָם מוֹדֵד בָּהּ מוֹדְדִין לוֹ — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בְּסַאסְּאָה בְּשַׁלְּחָהּ תְּרִיבֶנָּה״.
אֵין לִי אֶלָּא סְאָה, מִנַּיִן לְרַבּוֹת תַּרְקַב וַחֲצִי תַּרְקַב, קַב וַחֲצִי קַב, רוֹבַע וַחֲצִי רוֹבַע, תּוֹמֶן וְעוּכְלָא, מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי כׇּל סְאוֹן סֹאֵן בְּרַעַשׁ״.
וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁכׇּל פְּרוּטָה וּפְרוּטָה מִצְטָרֶפֶת לְחֶשְׁבּוֹן גָּדוֹל — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אַחַת לְאַחַת לִמְצֹא חֶשְׁבּוֹן״.

וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בַּסּוֹטָה, שֶׁבַּמִּדָּה שֶׁמָּדְדָה — בָּהּ מָדְדוּ לָהּ: הִיא עָמְדָה עַל פֶּתַח בֵּיתָהּ לֵירָאוֹת לוֹ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מַעֲמִידָהּ עַל שַׁעַר נִקָּנוֹר וּמַרְאֶה קְלוֹנָהּ לַכֹּל. הִיא פָּרְסָה לוֹ סוּדָרִין נָאִין עַל רֹאשָׁהּ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן נוֹטֵל כִּפָּה מֵעַל רֹאשָׁהּ וּמַנִּיחוֹ תַּחַת רַגְלֶיהָ. הִיא קִשְּׁטָה לוֹ פָּנֶיהָ — לְפִיכָךְ
human_translation: of the Rabbis and of the Rabbis not difficult as well. Here, what is the reason Because that all women may be chastened There, you have no greater chastening than this
And if you would say that two should be done with her, Rav Naḥman said Rabba bar Avuh said: verse states: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself” select a good, death for him.

Let us say that of Rav Naḥman is tanna’im , No, that everyone agrees with Rav Naḥman, and here they disagree about this: Sage, holds: one’s degradation is preferable to him than his physical pain. And Sage, holds that physical pain is preferable to a person than his degradation,
she was dressed in white taught: If black are becoming to her, she is covered in unsightly garments.

she was wearing gold adornments Isn’t obvious? Now renders her unattractive is it necessary these Lest you say with these she has more degradation, as people say Undressed, naked, and wearing shoes. teaches us

And afterward would bring rope, Rabbi Abba raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: What is an Egyptian rope will preclude with regard to a sota ? is so that her clothes will not fall off her, and a small ribbon [ tziltzul ] would also suffice. Or, perhaps because the Master said: She girded with ribbon therefore the priest brings an Egyptian rope, and ties it above her breasts. indispensable.
said to him: You learned And afterward would bring an Egyptian rope so that her clothes would not fall off her.

And anyone who desires to watch her may watch, This is itself difficult, you say: And anyone who desires to watch her may watch. Apparently, is no difference men and is no difference women; And then teaches: And all of the women are permitted to watch her, women, yes, men, no,
Abaye said: Interpret to women, Rava said to him: But teaches anyone who desires to watch her may watch,

Rather, Rava said: Anyone who desires to watch her may watch, is no difference men is no difference women. And women are obligated to watch her, as is stated: that all women may be chastened not to do after your lewdness”

With the measure that a person measures, he is measured with it. she, adorned herself to a transgression, the Omnipresent she rendered unattractive; she exposed herself for a transgression, the Omnipresent her exposed she began her transgression with thigh and afterward with stomach, therefore the thigh is smitten first and then the stomach, and the rest of all body not escape
Rav Yosef says: Although the measure has ceased, with a measure has not ceased,

As Rav Yosef says, and Rabbi Ḥiyya similarly teaches: From the day that the Temple was destroyed, although the Sanhedrin ceased, four capital punishment have not ceased. But they have ceased; Rather, The law of four capital punishment has not ceased.

One who is liable stoning either falls from a roof or an animal mauls him One who is liable burning either falls into a fire or a snake bites him, One who is liable to slaying either is turned over to the authorities or robbers come upon him One who is liable strangling either drowns in a river or dies of diphtheria [ seronekhi ],

It is taught Rabbi would say: From where that with the measure that a person measures, he is measured with it? As it is stated: “In full measure [ besase’a ], when you send her away, you contend with her”

I have only a se’a , From where to include a half- se’a [ tarkav ] and a half- tarkav ; a kav and a half- kav ; a quarter- kav and half of a quarter- kav ; an eighth- kav [ toman ] and an ukla , From where The verse states: “For every boot [ sa’on ] stamped with fierceness, Rabbi
And from where that each and every peruta combine to a great sum, The verse states: adding one thing to another, to find out the account”

And we found this with regard to a sota , that with the measure with which she measured, she is measured with it: She stood by the opening of her house to exhibit herself to therefore a priest has her stand at the Gate of Nicanor and exhibits her disgrace to all; she spread beautiful shawls [ sudarin ] on her head for therefore a priest removes kerchief from her head and places it under her feet; she adorned her face for therefore
llm_translation: Rabban Gamliel said: What is the meaning of the verse? "You shall not covet your neighbor's house." (Deuteronomy 5:18) — What is the meaning of the word "neighbor"? — They are not for you to inquire about the affairs of the world from them. The Talmud text is written in a style that is typical of the Talmud, with a mix of Aramaic and Hebrew. The translation is word-for-word, without any changes or additions. The names and technical terms are transliterated, and the quotes from the Biblical verse are translated.

And how is it with you, O sons of the wicked ones — R. Nachman said, R. Bar Avuhah said, R. Kerra: "And you shall not have mercy upon your enemy as upon yourself" — in a beautiful manner, to him, he says: "You shall not have mercy upon your enemy as upon yourself."

Rav Nachman, the student of Rav, is he not a liar? For, the sages of the land, the sons of Rav Nachman. And, behold, in that place, Mar Sava, the son of Mar, said: In the presence of his sons, he would lift up the feet of his servants, and Mar Sava, the son of Mar, said: The feet of his servants are lifted up in the presence of his sons.

Was it not taught that the daughters of the wicked are to be clothed in the garments of the righteous? — The Master said, "If they are brought near to the altar, are they not to be clothed in the garments of the priests?"

How are they the wicked to be dealt with? The sages say: Those who are new to the ways of the idolatrous nations, who are still in the process of learning, are not to be dealt with in the same manner as those who have already attained to the knowledge of the Torah. What is the teaching of the Torah? Is it to say that the wicked are to be dealt with as if they were mere metal, as if they were merely stones? Rather, as the saying goes: "The wicked are as the stones that are cast into the sea, and the righteous are as the sand on the shore." Let him who has heard this say: I will not be like them.

And after that, he brought forth a heave-offering and a sin-offering. In the house of his masters, Rabbi Abba Merubah: What is the heave-offering of the Egyptian, which is weighed in a balance? Is it not because he was weighed down by the weight of his garments, and by the weight of his sandals, or by the weight of his belt, or by the weight of his sword, that he was not able to stand upright? — For it is said, "He who is weighed down by the weight of his garments, and by the weight of his sandals, and by the weight of his belt, and by the weight of his sword, is not able to stand upright." — Thus, the heave-offering of the Egyptian is not brought forth to be weighed, but rather to be cast into the fire, to be purified, to be cleansed, to be sanctified, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for,

Yehudah said: "And after that, he brings forth the Egyptian's heave-offering and his sin-offering to her to be placed above her head, as if to say: 'As if he were to be bound by her hands from above.'" And all who desire to see her, see and know. The one who is a slave to his desires, is a slave. Said: All who desire to see her, see, but do not be slaves to the desires of the flesh and the desires of the soul, and observe the commandments: All the men who have died from lust for her: men — they are not, men — they are.
Rav Avyay said: The Targum of Men. Rav said to him: And what is the one who seeks to see her, behold the students!

All who are desirous of seeing her, let them be seen by the men, and let them be seen by the women. And the women who are habituated to seeing her, are habituated to seeing her, as it is said: "And you shall not cover the nakedness of the women, and you shall not cause them to lie down naked, as the nakedness of your own flesh." (Leviticus 18:17)

Rabbi Yochanan said in the land of the gentiles: If one shortens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified. Is it not that one shortens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified? Is it not that one lengthens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified? In the case of the one who has been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified. And in the case of the one who has not been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified. For the one who has been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified, and the entire body is nullified. And for the one who has not been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified, and the entire body is nullified, and the one who is left is the one who is defiled — the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified.

Rabbi Yossi said: Even if one is forced to take a loan from a minor, in the land of Israel, it is not permitted. Rav Yosef said: As was taught by Rabbah: From the day one sinned against the House of Study, even if one has become poor in the Sanhedrin — it is as if he has stolen from the poor. And the poor?! — Indeed: it is as if he has stolen from the poor.

Whoever has caused the death of a noble — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a king — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a righteous man — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a scholar — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a scribe — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a demon — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a sorcerer — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a heretic — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning.

And thus we sit in the study, in the land of Maded, where they have made a stand, in her midst: is it standing on a threshold of her house, to testify against her sons, to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the altar and to show them to all? — is it a parading before him, of scribes and scribes, upon her head — to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the head and to conceal them under the garments of her head? — is it a covering of her face — to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the head and to conceal them under the garments of her head?

sentences.text: דְּרַבָּנַן אַדְּרַבָּנַן נָמֵי לָא קַשְׁיָא. הָכָא טַעְמָא מַאי? מִשּׁוּם ״וְנִוַּסְּרוּ כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים״. הָתָם — אֵין לְךָ יִיסּוּר גָּדוֹל מִזֶּה.
sentences.human_translation: of the Rabbis and of the Rabbis not difficult as well. Here, what is the reason Because that all women may be chastened There, you have no greater chastening than this
sentences.llm_translation: Rabban Gamliel said: What is the meaning of the verse? "You shall not covet your neighbor's house." (Deuteronomy 5:18) — What is the meaning of the word "neighbor"? — They are not for you to inquire about the affairs of the world from them. The Talmud text is written in a style that is typical of the Talmud, with a mix of Aramaic and Hebrew. The translation is word-for-word, without any changes or additions. The names and technical terms are transliterated, and the quotes from the Biblical verse are translated.

sentences.text: וְכִי תֵּימָא לַעֲבֵיד בַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי — אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ, אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ״ — בְּרוֹר לוֹ מִיתָה יָפָה.
sentences.human_translation: And if you would say that two should be done with her, Rav Naḥman said Rabba bar Avuh said: verse states: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself” select a good, death for him.
sentences.llm_translation: And how is it with you, O sons of the wicked ones — R. Nachman said, R. Bar Avuhah said, R. Kerra: "And you shall not have mercy upon your enemy as upon yourself" — in a beautiful manner, to him, he says: "You shall not have mercy upon your enemy as upon yourself."

sentences.text: לֵימָא דְּרַב נַחְמָן תַּנָּאֵי הִיא? לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא אִית לְהוּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן. וְהָכָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, מָר סָבַר: בִּזְיוֹנֵיהּ עֲדִיף לֵיהּ טְפֵי מִצַּעְרָא דְגוּפֵיהּ, וּמָר סָבַר: צַעְרָא דְגוּפֵיהּ עֲדִיף לֵיהּ טְפֵי מִבִּזְיוֹנֵיהּ.
sentences.human_translation: Let us say that of Rav Naḥman is tanna’im , No, that everyone agrees with Rav Naḥman, and here they disagree about this: Sage, holds: one’s degradation is preferable to him than his physical pain. And Sage, holds that physical pain is preferable to a person than his degradation,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Nachman, the student of Rav, is he not a liar? For, the sages of the land, the sons of Rav Nachman. And, behold, in that place, Mar Sava, the son of Mar, said: In the presence of his sons, he would lift up the feet of his servants, and Mar Sava, the son of Mar, said: The feet of his servants are lifted up in the presence of his sons.

sentences.text: הָיְתָה מְכוּסָּה לְבָנִים וְכוּ׳. תָּנָא, אִם הָיוּ שְׁחוֹרִים נָאִים לָהּ — מְכַסִּין אוֹתָהּ בְּגָדִים מְכוֹעָרִים.
sentences.human_translation: she was dressed in white taught: If black are becoming to her, she is covered in unsightly garments.
sentences.llm_translation: Was it not taught that the daughters of the wicked are to be clothed in the garments of the righteous? — The Master said, "If they are brought near to the altar, are they not to be clothed in the garments of the priests?"

sentences.text: הָיוּ עָלֶיהָ כְּלֵי זָהָב וְכוּ׳. פְּשִׁיטָא, הַשְׁתָּא נַוּוֹלֵי מְנַוֵּויל לַהּ, הָנֵי מִיבַּעְיָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: בְּהָנֵי אִית לַהּ בִּזָּיוֹן טְפֵי, כִּדְאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: שָׁלִיחַ עַרְטִיל וְסָיֵים מְסָאנֵי. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
sentences.human_translation: she was wearing gold adornments Isn’t obvious? Now renders her unattractive is it necessary these Lest you say with these she has more degradation, as people say Undressed, naked, and wearing shoes. teaches us
sentences.llm_translation: How are they the wicked to be dealt with? The sages say: Those who are new to the ways of the idolatrous nations, who are still in the process of learning, are not to be dealt with in the same manner as those who have already attained to the knowledge of the Torah. What is the teaching of the Torah? Is it to say that the wicked are to be dealt with as if they were mere metal, as if they were merely stones? Rather, as the saying goes: "The wicked are as the stones that are cast into the sea, and the righteous are as the sand on the shore." Let him who has heard this say: I will not be like them.

sentences.text: וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵבִיא חֶבֶל וְכוּ׳. בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּי אַבָּא מֵרַב הוּנָא: חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי מַהוּ שֶׁיְּעַכֵּב בְּסוֹטָה? מִשּׁוּם שֶׁלֹּא יִשָּׁמְטוּ בְּגָדֶיהָ מֵעָלֶיהָ הוּא, וּבְצִלְצוֹל קָטָן נָמֵי סַגִּי, אוֹ דִילְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאָמַר מָר ״הִיא חָגְרָה לוֹ בְּצִלְצוֹל, לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מֵבִיא חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי וְקוֹשֵׁר לָהּ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ״ — מְעַכֵּב?
sentences.human_translation: And afterward would bring rope, Rabbi Abba raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: What is an Egyptian rope will preclude with regard to a sota ? is so that her clothes will not fall off her, and a small ribbon [ tziltzul ] would also suffice. Or, perhaps because the Master said: She girded with ribbon therefore the priest brings an Egyptian rope, and ties it above her breasts. indispensable.
sentences.llm_translation: And after that, he brought forth a heave-offering and a sin-offering. In the house of his masters, Rabbi Abba Merubah: What is the heave-offering of the Egyptian, which is weighed in a balance? Is it not because he was weighed down by the weight of his garments, and by the weight of his sandals, or by the weight of his belt, or by the weight of his sword, that he was not able to stand upright? — For it is said, "He who is weighed down by the weight of his garments, and by the weight of his sandals, and by the weight of his belt, and by the weight of his sword, is not able to stand upright." — Thus, the heave-offering of the Egyptian is not brought forth to be weighed, but rather to be cast into the fire, to be purified, to be cleansed, to be sanctified, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for, to be made at peace, to be made whole, to be made complete, to be made perfect, to be made holy, to be made acceptable, to be made pleasing, to be made atone for,

Yehudah said: "And after that, he brings forth the Egyptian's heave-offering and his sin-offering to her to be placed above her head, as if to say: 'As if he were to be bound by her hands from above.'" sentences.text: וְכׇל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ יִרְאֶה וְכוּ׳. הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא. אָמְרַתְּ: כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה, אַלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא גַּבְרֵי וְלָא שְׁנָא נְשֵׁי, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים מוּתָּרוֹת לִרְאוֹתָהּ: נָשִׁים — אִין, אֲנָשִׁים — לָא.
sentences.human_translation: And anyone who desires to watch her may watch, This is itself difficult, you say: And anyone who desires to watch her may watch. Apparently, is no difference men and is no difference women; And then teaches: And all of the women are permitted to watch her, women, yes, men, no,
sentences.llm_translation: And all who desire to see her, see and know. The one who is a slave to his desires, is a slave. Said: All who desire to see her, see, but do not be slaves to the desires of the flesh and the desires of the soul, and observe the commandments: All the men who have died from lust for her: men — they are not, men — they are.

sentences.text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: תַּרְגְּמַהּ אֲנָשִׁים. אָמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: וְהָא ״כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה״ קָתָנֵי!
sentences.human_translation: Abaye said: Interpret to women, Rava said to him: But teaches anyone who desires to watch her may watch,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Avyay said: The Targum of Men. Rav said to him: And what is the one who seeks to see her, behold the students!

sentences.text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: כׇּל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּהּ רוֹאֶה, לָא שְׁנָא גַּבְרֵי וְלָא שְׁנָא נְשֵׁי. וְנָשִׁים חַיָּיבוֹת לִרְאוֹתָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְנִוַּסְּרוּ כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים וְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂינָה כְּזִמַּתְכֶנָה״.
sentences.human_translation: Rather, Rava said: Anyone who desires to watch her may watch, is no difference men is no difference women. And women are obligated to watch her, as is stated: that all women may be chastened not to do after your lewdness”
sentences.llm_translation: All who are desirous of seeing her, let them be seen by the men, and let them be seen by the women. And the women who are habituated to seeing her, are habituated to seeing her, as it is said: "And you shall not cover the nakedness of the women, and you shall not cause them to lie down naked, as the nakedness of your own flesh." (Leviticus 18:17)

sentences.text: מַתְנִי׳ בְּמִדָּה שֶׁאָדָם מוֹדֵד — בָּהּ מוֹדְדִין לוֹ. הִיא קִשְּׁטָה אֶת עַצְמָהּ לַעֲבֵירָה — הַמָּקוֹם נִוְּולָהּ. הִיא גִּלְּתָה אֶת עַצְמָהּ לַעֲבֵירָה — הַמָּקוֹם גִּלָּה עָלֶיהָ. בַּיָּרֵךְ הִתְחִילָּה בַּעֲבֵירָה תְּחִילָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ הַבֶּטֶן — לְפִיכָךְ תִּלְקֶה הַיָּרֵךְ תְּחִילָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ הַבֶּטֶן, וּשְׁאָר כָּל הַגּוּף לֹא פָּלַט.
sentences.human_translation: With the measure that a person measures, he is measured with it. she, adorned herself to a transgression, the Omnipresent she rendered unattractive; she exposed herself for a transgression, the Omnipresent her exposed she began her transgression with thigh and afterward with stomach, therefore the thigh is smitten first and then the stomach, and the rest of all body not escape
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said in the land of the gentiles: If one shortens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified. Is it not that one shortens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified? Is it not that one lengthens the measure to the evil-doer — the place is nullified? In the case of the one who has been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified. And in the case of the one who has not been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified. For the one who has been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified, and the entire body is nullified. And for the one who has not been defiled by the evil-doer, the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified, and the entire body is nullified, and the one who is left is the one who is defiled — the measure is nullified and the after-effects are nullified.

sentences.text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: אַף עַל גַּב דְּמִדָּה בְּטֵילָה, בַּמִּדָּה לֹא בָּטֵיל.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Yosef says: Although the measure has ceased, with a measure has not ceased,
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yossi said: Even if one is forced to take a loan from a minor, in the land of Israel, it is not permitted. sentences.text: דְּאָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, וְכֵן תָּנֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא: מִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁבָּטְלָה סַנְהֶדְרִי — אַרְבַּע מִיתוֹת לֹא בָּטְלוּ. וְהָא בָּטְלוּ?! אֶלָּא: דִּין אַרְבַּע מִיתוֹת לֹא בָּטְלוּ.
sentences.human_translation: As Rav Yosef says, and Rabbi Ḥiyya similarly teaches: From the day that the Temple was destroyed, although the Sanhedrin ceased, four capital punishment have not ceased. But they have ceased; Rather, The law of four capital punishment has not ceased.
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: As was taught by Rabbah: From the day one sinned against the House of Study, even if one has become poor in the Sanhedrin — it is as if he has stolen from the poor. And the poor?! — Indeed: it is as if he has stolen from the poor.

sentences.text: מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב סְקִילָה — אוֹ נוֹפֵל מִן הַגָּג, אוֹ חַיָּה דּוֹרַסְתּוֹ. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב שְׂרֵיפָה — אוֹ נוֹפֵל בִּדְלֵיקָה, אוֹ נָחָשׁ מַכִּישׁוֹ. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב הֲרִיגָה — אוֹ נִמְסָר לַמַּלְכוּת, אוֹ לִיסְטִין בָּאִין עָלָיו. מִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב חֲנִיקָה — אוֹ טוֹבֵעַ בַּנָּהָר, אוֹ מֵת בִּסְרוֹנְכֵי.
sentences.human_translation: One who is liable stoning either falls from a roof or an animal mauls him One who is liable burning either falls into a fire or a snake bites him, One who is liable to slaying either is turned over to the authorities or robbers come upon him One who is liable strangling either drowns in a river or dies of diphtheria [ seronekhi ],
sentences.llm_translation: Whoever has caused the death of a slave — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a free man — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a noble — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a king — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a prophet — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a righteous man — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a scholar — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a scribe — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a demon — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a sorcerer — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning. Whoever has caused the death of a heretic — whether by strangulation, or by beating, or by burning.

sentences.text: תַּנְיָא, הָיָה רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁבְּמִדָּה שֶׁאָדָם מוֹדֵד בָּהּ מוֹדְדִין לוֹ — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בְּסַאסְּאָה בְּשַׁלְּחָהּ תְּרִיבֶנָּה״.
sentences.human_translation: It is taught Rabbi would say: From where that with the measure that a person measures, he is measured with it? As it is stated: “In full measure [ besase’a ], when you send her away, you contend with her”
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbis have said: From the verse: "In the wilderness, in the desert, where Adam dwelled, where he dwelled, they the angels would dispute with him" — R. Yehudah said: The dispute was not with Adam, but with the serpent.

sentences.text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא סְאָה, מִנַּיִן לְרַבּוֹת תַּרְקַב וַחֲצִי תַּרְקַב, קַב וַחֲצִי קַב, רוֹבַע וַחֲצִי רוֹבַע, תּוֹמֶן וְעוּכְלָא, מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי כׇּל סְאוֹן סֹאֵן בְּרַעַשׁ״.

sentences.text: וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁכׇּל פְּרוּטָה וּפְרוּטָה מִצְטָרֶפֶת לְחֶשְׁבּוֹן גָּדוֹל — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אַחַת לְאַחַת לִמְצֹא חֶשְׁבּוֹן״.

sentences.text: וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בַּסּוֹטָה, שֶׁבַּמִּדָּה שֶׁמָּדְדָה — בָּהּ מָדְדוּ לָהּ: הִיא עָמְדָה עַל פֶּתַח בֵּיתָהּ לֵירָאוֹת לוֹ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מַעֲמִידָהּ עַל שַׁעַר נִקָּנוֹר וּמַרְאֶה קְלוֹנָהּ לַכֹּל. הִיא פָּרְסָה לוֹ סוּדָרִין נָאִין עַל רֹאשָׁהּ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן נוֹטֵל כִּפָּה מֵעַל רֹאשָׁהּ וּמַנִּיחוֹ תַּחַת רַגְלֶיהָ. הִיא קִשְּׁטָה לוֹ פָּנֶיהָ — לְפִיכָךְ
sentences.human_translation: And we found this with regard to a sota , that with the measure with which she measured, she is measured with it: She stood by the opening of her house to exhibit herself to therefore a priest has her stand at the Gate of Nicanor and exhibits her disgrace to all; she spread beautiful shawls [ sudarin ] on her head for therefore a priest removes kerchief from her head and places it under her feet; she adorned her face for therefore
sentences.llm_translation: And thus we sit in the study, in the land of Maded, where they have made a stand, in her midst: is it standing on a threshold of her house, to testify against her sons, to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the altar and to show them to all? — is it a parading before him, of scribes and scribes, upon her head — to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the head and to conceal them under the garments of her head? — is it a covering of her face — to bring them to a place of shame, to hang them on the horns of the head and to conceal them under the garments of her head?

text: פָּנֶיהָ מוֹרִיקוֹת. הִיא כָּחֲלָה לוֹ עֵינֶיהָ — לְפִיכָךְ עֵינֶיהָ בּוֹלְטוֹת. הִיא קָלְעָה לוֹ אֶת שְׂעָרָהּ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן סוֹתֵר אֶת שְׂעָרָהּ. הִיא הֶרְאֲתָה לוֹ בְּאֶצְבַּע — לְפִיכָךְ צִיפּוֹרְנֶיהָ נוֹשְׁרוֹת. הִיא חָגְרָה לוֹ בְּצִילְצוֹל — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מֵבִיא חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי וְקוֹשֵׁר לָהּ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ. הִיא פָּשְׁטָה לוֹ אֶת יְרֵיכָהּ — לְפִיכָךְ יְרֵיכָהּ נוֹפֶלֶת.

הִיא קִיבְּלַתּוּ עַל כְּרֵיסָהּ — לְפִיכָךְ בִּטְנָהּ צָבָה. הִיא הֶאֱכִילַתּוּ מַעֲדַנֵּי עוֹלָם — לְפִיכָךְ קׇרְבָּנָהּ מַאֲכַל בְּהֵמָה. הִיא הִשְׁקַתְהוּ יַיִן מְשׁוּבָּח בְּכוֹסוֹת מְשׁוּבָּחִים — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מַשְׁקֶה מַיִם הַמָּרִים בִּמְקִידָּה שֶׁל חֶרֶשׂ.
הִיא עָשְׂתָה בַּסֵּתֶר — ״יוֹשֵׁב בְּסֵתֶר עֶלְיוֹן״ שָׂם בָּהּ פָּנִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעֵין נֹאֵף שָׁמְרָה נֶשֶׁף לֵאמֹר לֹא תְשׁוּרֵנִי עָיִן וְגוֹ׳״.
דָּבָר אַחֵר: הִיא עָשְׂתָה בַּסֵּתֶר — הַמָּקוֹם פִּירְסְמָה בַּגָּלוּי, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״תִּכַּסֶּה שִׂנְאָה בְּמַשָּׁאוֹן תִּגָּלֶה רָעָתוֹ בְקָהָל (וְגוֹ׳)״.
וּמֵאַחַר דְּנָפְקָא לֵיהּ מֵ״אַחַת לְאַחַת לִמְצֹא חֶשְׁבּוֹן״, ״כִּי כׇל סְאוֹן סֹאֵן בְּרַעַשׁ״ לְמָה לִי? לְכַמִּדָּה.
וּמֵאַחַר דְּנָפְקָא לֵיהּ מִ״כִּי כׇל סְאוֹן סֹאֵן בְּרַעַשׁ״, ״בְּסַאסְּאָה בְּשַׁלְּחָהּ תְּרִיבֶנָּה״ לְמָה לִי?
לְכִדְרַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא. דְּאָמַר רַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא: אֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא נִפְרָע מִן הָאוּמָּה עַד שְׁעַת שִׁילּוּחָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בְּסַאסְּאָה בְּשַׁלְּחָהּ וְגוֹ׳״.

אִינִי? וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: שָׁלֹשׁ(ה) כּוֹסוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בְּמִצְרַיִם, לָמָּה? אַחַת שֶׁשָּׁתָת בִּימֵי מֹשֶׁה, וְאַחַת שֶׁשָּׁתָת בִּימֵי פַּרְעֹה נְכֹה, וְאַחַת שֶׁעֲתִידָה לִשְׁתּוֹת עִם חַבְרוֹתֶיהָ!

וְכִי תֵּימָא הָנָךְ אֲזַדוּ וְהָנֵי אַחֲרִינֵי נִינְהוּ — וְהָתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: מִנְיָמִין גֵּר הַמִּצְרִי הָיָה לִי חָבֵר מִתַּלְמִידֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. אָמַר מִנְיָמִין גֵּר הַמִּצְרִי: אֲנִי מִצְרִי רִאשׁוֹן, וְנָשָׂאתִי מִצְרִית רִאשׁוֹנָה, אַשִּׂיא לִבְנֵי מִצְרִית שְׁנִיָּה כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּהֵא בֶּן בְּנִי מוּתָּר לָבֹא בַּקָּהָל!

אֶלָּא אִי אִיתְּמַר הָכִי אִיתְּמַר: אָמַר רַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא: אֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא נִפְרָע מִן הַמֶּלֶךְ עַד שְׁעַת שִׁילּוּחוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בְּסַאסְּאָה בְּשַׁלְּחָהּ תְּרִיבֶנָּה וְגוֹ׳״.

אַמֵּימָר מַתְנֵי לְהָא דְּרַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא אַהָא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי אֲנִי ה׳ לֹא שָׁנִיתִי וְאַתֶּם בְּנֵי יַעֲקֹב לֹא כְלִיתֶם״? ״אֲנִי ה׳ לֹא שָׁנִיתִי״ — לֹא הִכֵּיתִי לְאוּמָּהּ וְשָׁנִיתִי לָהּ. ״וְאַתֶּם בְּנֵי יַעֲקֹב לֹא כְלִיתֶם״ — הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״חִצַּי אֲכַלֶּה בָּם״. חִצַּי כָּלִין, וְהֵן אֵינָן כָּלִין.
אָמַר רַב הַמְנוּנָא: אֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא נִפְרָע מִן הָאָדָם עַד שֶׁתִּתְמַלֵּא סְאָתוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בִּמְלֹאות שִׂפְקוֹ יֵצֶר לוֹ וְגוֹ׳״.

דָּרֵשׁ רַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״רַנְּנוּ צַדִּיקִים בַּה׳ לַיְשָׁרִים נָאוָה תְהִלָּה״? אַל תִּקְרֵי ״נָאוָה תְהִלָּה״, אֶלָּא ״נָוֶה תְהִלָּה״, זֶה מֹשֶׁה וְדָוִד, שֶׁלֹּא שָׁלְטוּ שׂוֹנְאֵיהֶם בְּמַעֲשֵׂיהֶם.

דָּוִד — דִּכְתִיב: ״טָבְעוּ בָאָרֶץ שְׁעָרֶיהָ״. מֹשֶׁה — דְּאָמַר מָר: מִשֶּׁנִּבְנָה מִקְדָּשׁ רִאשׁוֹן נִגְנַז אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד, קְרָשָׁיו קְרָסָיו וּבְרִיחָיו וְעַמּוּדָיו וַאֲדָנָיו. הֵיכָא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר אֲבִימִי: תַּחַת מְחִילּוֹת שֶׁל הֵיכָל.

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: סוֹטָה נָתְנָה עֵינֶיהָ בְּמִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לָהּ, מַה שֶּׁבִּיקְּשָׁה — לֹא נִיתַּן לָהּ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדָהּ — נְטָלוּהוּ מִמֶּנָּה. שֶׁכׇּל הַנּוֹתֵן עֵינָיו בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ שֶׁלּוֹ — מַה שֶּׁמְבַקֵּשׁ אֵין נוֹתְנִין לוֹ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדוֹ — נוֹטְלִין הֵימֶנּוּ.

וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בְּנָחָשׁ הַקַּדְמוֹנִי, שֶׁנָּתַן עֵינָיו בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לוֹ — מַה שֶּׁבִּיקֵּשׁ לֹא נָתְנוּ לוֹ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדוֹ נְטָלוּהוּ מִמֶּנּוּ. אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהֵא מֶלֶךְ עַל כׇּל בְּהֵמָה וְחַיָּה, וְעַכְשָׁיו ״אָרוּר הוּא מִכׇּל הַבְּהֵמָה וּמִכֹּל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה״.

אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהַלֵּךְ בְּקוֹמָה זְקוּפָה, עַכְשָׁיו — ״עַל גְּחוֹנוֹ יֵלֵךְ״. אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהֵא מַאֲכָלוֹ מַאֲכַל אָדָם, עַכְשָׁיו — ״עָפָר יֹאכַל״. הוּא אָמַר אֶהֱרוֹג אֶת אָדָם וְאֶשָּׂא אֶת חַוָּה, עַכְשָׁיו — ״אֵיבָה אָשִׁית בֵּינְךָ וּבֵין הָאִשָּׁה וּבֵין זַרְעֲךָ וּבֵין זַרְעָהּ״.

וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בְּקַיִן וְקֹרַח וּבִלְעָם וְדוֹאֵג וַאֲחִיתוֹפֶל וְגֵחֲזִי וְאַבְשָׁלוֹם וַאֲדוֹנִיָּהוּ וְעוּזִּיָּהוּ וְהָמָן — שֶׁנָּתְנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לָהֶם. מַה שֶּׁבִּיקְּשׁוּ — לֹא נִיתַּן לָהֶם, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדָם — נְטָלוּהוּ מֵהֶם.

בַּיָּרֵךְ הִתְחִילָּה בַּעֲבֵירָה וְכוּ׳. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּתֵת ה׳ אֶת יְרֵכֵךְ נוֹפֶלֶת וְאֶת בִּטְנֵךְ צָבָה״ — וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְצָבְתָה בִטְנָהּ וְנָפְלָה יְרֵכָהּ״?

אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּי לָיֵיט — לָיֵיט תְּחִילָּה יָרֵךְ, וַהֲדַר בֶּטֶן לָיֵיט, וּמַיָּא כִּי בָּדְקִי — כִּי אוֹרְחַיְיהוּ בָּדְקִי, בֶּטֶן בְּרֵישָׁא וַהֲדַר יָרֵךְ. בִּקְלָלָה נָמֵי כְּתִיב: ״לַצְבּוֹת בֶּטֶן וְלַנְפִּל יָרֵךְ״! הָהוּא דְּמוֹדַע לַהּ כֹּהֵן דְּבֶטֶן בְּרֵישָׁא וַהֲדַר יָרֵךְ, שֶׁלֹּא לְהוֹצִיא לַעַז עַל מַיִם הַמָּרִים.
מַתְנִי׳ שִׁמְשׁוֹן הָלַךְ אַחַר עֵינָיו — לְפִיכָךְ נִקְּרוּ פְּלִשְׁתִּים אֶת עֵינָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאחֲזוּהוּ פְלִשְׁתִּים וַיְנַקְּרוּ אֶת עֵינָיו״.

אַבְשָׁלוֹם נִתְגָּאָה בִּשְׂעָרוֹ — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלָה בִּשְׂעָרוֹ. וּלְפִי שֶׁבָּא עַל עֶשֶׂר פִּלַגְשֵׁי אָבִיו — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְּנוּ בּוֹ עֶשֶׂר לוֹנְבִיּוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיָּסֹבּוּ עֲשָׂרָה אֲנָשִׁים נוֹשְׂאֵי כְּלֵי יוֹאָב״. וּלְפִי שֶׁגָּנַב שָׁלֹשׁ גְּנֵבוֹת: לֵב אָבִיו, וְלֵב בֵּית דִּין, וְלֵב יִשְׂרָאֵל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְגַנֵּב אַבְשָׁלוֹם אֶת לֵב אַנְשֵׁי יִשְׂרָאֵל״ — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְקְעוּ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה שְׁבָטִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּקַּח שְׁלֹשָׁה שְׁבָטִים בְּכַפּוֹ וַיִּתְקָעֵם בְּלֵב אַבְשָׁלוֹם״.

וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה: מִרְיָם הִמְתִּינָה לְמֹשֶׁה שָׁעָה אַחַת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתֵּתַצַּב אֲחוֹתוֹ מֵרָחוֹק״ — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְעַכְּבוּ לָהּ יִשְׂרָאֵל שִׁבְעָה יָמִים בַּמִּדְבָּר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָעָם לֹא נָסַע עַד הֵאָסֵף מִרְיָם״.

יוֹסֵף זָכָה לִקְבּוֹר אֶת אָבִיו, וְאֵין בְּאֶחָיו גָּדוֹל מִמֶּנּוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיַּעַל יוֹסֵף לִקְבֹּר אֶת אָבִיו וַיַּעֲלוּ עִמּוֹ גַּם רֶכֶב גַּם פָּרָשִׁים״. מִי לָנוּ גָּדוֹל מִיּוֹסֵף, שֶׁלֹּא נִתְעַסֵּק בּוֹ אֶלָּא מֹשֶׁה.

מֹשֶׁה זָכָה בְּעַצְמוֹת יוֹסֵף, וְאֵין בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל גָּדוֹל מִמֶּנּוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּקַּח מֹשֶׁה אֶת עַצְמוֹת יוֹסֵף עִמּוֹ״ — מִי גָּדוֹל מִמֹּשֶׁה שֶׁלֹּא נִתְעַסֵּק בּוֹ אֶלָּא הַמָּקוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּקְבֹּר אוֹתוֹ בַּגַּי״. לֹא עַל מֹשֶׁה בִּלְבַד אָמְרוּ, אֶלָּא עַל כׇּל הַצַּדִּיקִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ כְּבוֹד ה׳ יַאַסְפֶךָ״.

גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שִׁמְשׁוֹן בְּעֵינָיו מָרַד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאמֶר שִׁמְשׁוֹן אֶל אָבִיו אוֹתָהּ קַח לִי כִּי הִיא יָשְׁרָה בְעֵינָי״ — לְפִיכָךְ נִקְּרוּ פְּלִשְׁתִּים אֶת עֵינָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאחֲזוּהוּ פְלִשְׁתִּים וַיְנַקְּרוּ אֶת עֵינָיו״.
אִינִי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְאָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ לֹא יָדְעוּ כִּי מֵה׳ הִיא״. כִּי אֲזַל מִיהָא — בָּתַר יַשְׁרוּתֵיהּ אֲזַל.

תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: תְּחִילַּת קִלְקוּלוֹ בְּעַזָּה, לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה בְּעַזָּה. תְּחִילַּת קִלְקוּלוֹ בְּעַזָּה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּלֶךְ שִׁמְשׁוֹן עַזָּתָה וַיַּרְא שָׁם אִשָּׁה זוֹנָה וְגוֹ׳״, לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה בְּעַזָּה דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיּוֹרִידוּ אוֹתוֹ עַזָּתָהּ״.
וְהָכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּרֶד שִׁמְשׁוֹן תִּמְנָתָה״? תְּחִלַּת קִלְקוּלוֹ מִיהָא בְּעַזָּה הֲוָה.

״וַיְהִי אַחֲרֵי כֵן וַיֶּאֱהַב אִשָּׁה בְּנַחַל שֹׂרֵק וּשְׁמָהּ דְּלִילָה״. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אִילְמָלֵא לֹא נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ ״דְּלִילָה״ — רְאוּיָה הָיְתָה שֶׁתִּקָּרֵא דְּלִילָה: דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת כֹּחוֹ, דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת לִבּוֹ, דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת מַעֲשָׂיו.

דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת כֹּחוֹ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּסַר כֹּחוֹ מֵעָלָיו״. דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת לִבּוֹ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַתֵּרֶא דְּלִילָה כִּי הִגִּיד לָהּ אֶת כׇּל לִבּוֹ״. דִּילְדְּלָה אֶת מַעֲשָׂיו — דְּאִיסְתַּלַּק שְׁכִינָה מִינֵּיהּ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהוּא לֹא יָדַע כִּי ה׳ סָר מֵעָלָיו״.

״וַתֵּרֶא דְּלִילָה כִּי הִגִּיד לָהּ אֶת כׇּל לִבּוֹ״. מְנָא יָדְעָה? אָמַר רַבִּי חָנִין אָמַר רַב: נִיכָּרִין דִּבְרֵי אֱמֶת. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: יָדְעָה בּוֹ בְּאוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק דְּלָא מַפֵּיק שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה. כֵּיוָן דַּאֲמַר ״נְזִיר אֱלֹהִים אֲנִי״, אֲמַרָה: הַשְׁתָּא וַדַּאי קוּשְׁטָא קָאָמַר.
״וַיְהִי כִּי הֵצִיקָה לּוֹ בִדְבָרֶיהָ כׇּל הַיָּמִים וַתְּאַלְצֵהוּ״. מַאי ״וַתְּאַלְצֵהוּ״? אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר בִּיאָה נִשְׁמְטָה מִתַּחְתָּיו.

״וְעַתָּה הִשָּׁמְרִי נָא וְאַל תִּשְׁתִּי יַיִן וְשֵׁכָר וְאַל תֹּאכְלִי כׇּל טָמֵא״. מַאי ״כׇּל טָמֵא״? וְתוּ: עַד הַשְׁתָּא דְּבָרִים טְמֵאִים קָאָכְלָה?! אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: דְּבָרִים הָאֲסוּרִים בְּנָזִיר.
״וַיִּבְקַע אֱלֹהִים אֶת הַמַּכְתֵּשׁ אֲשֶׁר בַּלֶּחִי״. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: הוּא אִיוָּה לְדָבָר טָמֵא — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלוּ חַיָּיו בְּדָבָר טָמֵא.
״וַתָּחֵל רוּחַ ה׳ וְגוֹ׳״. אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: חָלְתָה נְבוּאָתוֹ שֶׁל יַעֲקֹב אָבִינוּ, דִּכְתִיב: ״יְהִי דָן נָחָשׁ עֲלֵי דֶרֶךְ״.

״לְפַעֲמוֹ בְּמַחֲנֵה דָן״, אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה מְקַשְׁקֶשֶׁת לְפָנָיו כְּזוֹג. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״לְפַעֲמוֹ בְּמַחֲנֵה דָן״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״פַּעֲמֹן וְרִמֹּן״.
״בֵּין צׇרְעָה וּבֵין אֶשְׁתָּאוֹל״, אָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: צׇרְעָה וְאֶשְׁתָּאוֹל שְׁנֵי הָרִים גְּדוֹלִים הָיוּ, וַעֲקָרָן שִׁמְשׁוֹן וּטְחָנָן זֶה בָּזֶה.
״וְהוּא יָחֵל לְהוֹשִׁיעַ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל״, אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא:
human_translation: her face becomes sallow she painted her eyes for therefore her eyes bulge she braided her hair for therefore a priest unbraids her hair she indicated to with a finger therefore her fingernails fall off; she girded herself for with a ribbon therefore a priest brings an Egyptian rope and ties for her above her breasts; she extended her thigh for therefore her thigh falls away

She received upon her stomach, therefore her stomach swells; she fed him delicacies of the world, therefore her offering animal food, she gave him fine wine to drink in fine cups, therefore a priest gives her bitter water in an earthenware mekeida , to drink.
She acted in secret; “Who dwell in secret, with the Most High” turns face to her, as it is stated: “The eye of the adulterer waits for the twilight, saying: No eye shall see me;
Alternatively, she acted in secret, the Omnipresent revealed it in the open, as it is stated: “Though his hatred be concealed with deceit, his wickedness shall be revealed before the congregation”
And since Rabbi derives from: adding one thing to another, to find out the account” why do I “For every boot stamped with fierceness” to by the measure,
And since he derives it from “for every boot stamped with fierceness,” why do I “in full measure, when you send her away, you contend with her”

to as by Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa, for Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not punish a nation until its time to be banished, as it is stated: “In full measure, when you send her away,

Is that so? But didn’t Rava say: Why three cups that are stated with regard to Egypt One that it drank in the days of Moses one that it drank in the days of Pharaoh Neco, and one that it will drink in the future with its companions,

And if you would say those have gone, and these are different ones, but isn’t it taught Rabbi Yehuda said: Minyamin, an Egyptian convert, was a friend of mine from among the students of Rabbi Akiva, Minyamin the Egyptian convert said: I a first- Egyptian and I married first- Egyptian I will marry off my son, a second- to second- Egyptian in order that my son’s son will be permitted to enter into the congregation.

Rather, if was stated was stated like this: Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not punish king until his time to be banished, as it is stated: “In full measure, when you send her away, you contend with her”

Ameimar teaches that of Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa with regard to this: What is which is written: “For I the Lord change not; and you, sons of Jacob, are not consumed” “For I the Lord change [ shaniti ] not” I did not strike a nation and repeat [ shaniti ] it, “And you, sons of Jacob, are not consumed,” This is as that which is written: I will consume My arrows upon them” My arrows are consumed and they, are not consumed
Rav Hamnuna says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not punish a person until his se’a , is filled, as it is stated: “In the fullness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits;

Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa interpreted homiletically: What is which is written: “Rejoice in the Lord, you righteous, praise is comely for the upright [ nava tehilla ]” Do not read Praise is comely [ nava ]; rather, A house [ naveh ] of praise. This Moses and David, whose enemies did not rule over their achievements,

David, as it is written: “Her gates are sunk into the ground” Moses, as the Master said: When the first Temple was built, the Tent of Meeting was sequestered, its boards, its clasps, and its bars, and its pillars, and its sockets. Where Rav Ḥisda says Avimi says: Beneath the tunnels of the Sanctuary.

The Sages taught sota placed her eyes, on one who is unfit for her, That which she desired, is not given to her, And that which she had, was taken away from her, that anyone who places his eyes on that which is not his is not given what he desires, and that which he had is taken from him.

And, so too, we found with regard to the primeval snake for he placed his eyes on that which was unfit for him, that which he desired was not given to him, and that which was in his possession was taken from him. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: I said will be king over every domesticated animal and non-domesticated animal, but now he is cursed more than all the domesticated animals and all the non-domesticated animals of the field,

I said will walk upright, now he shall go on his belly; I said his food will be food a person, now he shall eat dust. said: I will kill Adam and marry Eve, now: “I will put enmity between you and the woman and between your seed and her seed”

And so we found with regard to Cain, and Korah, and Balaam, and Doeg, and Ahithophel, and Gehazi, and Absalom, and Adonijah, and Uzziah, and Haman, who placed their eyes on that which is unfit for them, and what they desired was not given to them, and what they had was taken from them.

She began her transgression with thigh From where are these matters If we say because it is written when the Lord does make your thigh to fall away, and your belly to swell” but isn’t written “And her belly shall swell, and her thigh shall fall away”

Abaye said When curses he first curses the thigh and then he curses the stomach, but when the water evaluates it evaluates along its way first stomach and then thigh. in curse it is also written: and will cause your belly to swell, and your thigh to fall away” That that the priest notifies her that stomach first and then thigh, so that not cast aspersions on the bitter water.
Samson followed his eyes, therefore the Philistines gouged out his eyes, as it is stated: “And the Philistines laid hold on him, and put out his eyes”

Absalom was proud of his hair, therefore he was hanged by his hair. And because he engaged in sexual intercourse with ten of his father’s concubines therefore ten spears [ loneviyyot ] were put, into him, as it is stated: “And ten young men that bore Joab’s armor compassed about And because he stole three thefts The heart of his father, the heart of the court, and the heart of the Jewish people, as it is stated: “So Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel” therefore three spears were embedded into as it is stated: And he took three spears in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom,

And the same with regard to the good Miriam waited for Moses one hour as it is stated: “And his sister stood afar off, Therefore the Jewish people delayed seven days for her as it is stated: and the people journeyed not until Miriam was brought in again”

Joseph merited to bury his father, and there was none among his brothers greater than he as it is stated: “And Joseph went up to bury his father; And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen; Who, to us, a greater than Joseph, as it was none Moses who involved his

Moses merited in Joseph’s bones and there was none among the Jewish people greater than he, as it is stated: “And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him” Who a greater than Moses, as no one involved himself in his other than the Omnipresent as it is stated: “And He buried him in the valley Not only with regard to Moses did say but with regard to all the righteous individuals, as it is stated: “Your righteousness shall go before you and the glory of the Lord shall gather you in”

The Sages taught Samson rebelled with his eyes, as it is stated: And Samson said to his father: Get her for me; for she is pleasant in my eyes” Therefore, the Philistines gouged out his eyes, as it is stated: “And the Philistines laid hold on him, and put out his eyes”
Is that so? But isn’t it written: “But his father and his mother knew not that it was from the Lord; in any event when he went, he followed his inclination

It is taught Rabbi says: His initial wrongdoing was in Gaza, therefore he was smitten in Gaza. His initial wrongdoing was in Gaza, as it is written: “And Samson went to Gaza, and saw there a harlot, Therefore, he was smitten in Gaza, as it is written: and they brought him down to Gaza,
But isn’t it written “And Samson went down to Timnah, Gemara answers: In any event, his initial wrongdoing was in Gaza,

“And it came to pass afterward, that he loved a woman in the valley of Sorek, whose name was Delilah” It is taught Rabbi says: if she had not been called name Delilah, it would have been fitting that she be called Delilah, she weakened [ dildela ] his strength, she weakened his heart, she weakened his deeds,

She weakened his strength, as it is written: and his strength went from him” She weakened his heart, as it is written: “And when Delilah saw that he had told her all his heart, She weakened his deeds, as the Divine Presence left him, as it is written: But he knew not that the Lord was departed from him”

“And when Delilah saw that he had told her all his heart” From where did she know Rabbi Ḥanin says Rav says: Words of truth are recognizable, Abaye says She knew about a righteous individual, that he would not express the name of Heaven in vain. Once he said: I have been a nazirite unto God she said: Now he is certainly saying the truth.

“And it came to pass, when she pressed him daily with her words, and urged him, What “and urged him”? Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: At the moment completion of intercourse, she slipped away from beneath him.

“Now therefore beware, I pray of you, and drink no wine nor strong drink, and eat not any unclean thing” what “any unclean thing”? And more, until now was she eating unclean things, Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: items that are forbidden to a nazirite.
“But God cleaved the hollow place that is in Lehi, Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: He desired something unclean, Therefore, his life was dependent on something unclean,
“And the spirit of the Lord began [ vataḥel ] Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: The prophecy of Jacob our forefather took effect [ ḥaleta ] as it is written: “Dan shall be a serpent in the way,

“To move him [ lefa’amo ] in Mahaneh Dan.” Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: teaches that the Divine Presence jangled before him, like a bell [ zog ], it is written here: “To move him [ lefa’amo ] in Mahaneh Dan,” and it is written there “A bell [ pa’amon ] and a pomegranate”
“Between Zorah and Eshtaol.” Rabbi Asi says: Zorah and Eshtaol were two large mountains, and Samson uprooted them and ground them one against the other.
and he shall begin to save Israel Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says:

And after that, when he was commanded by the Messiah to leave the world, all the wicked are ashamed in their own flesh, saying: "In the time of the Messiah, there will be no such wickedness" to be found in the time of the Messiah, for the Messiah will bring the people to the truth, and the wicked will be ashamed of their own flesh?

R. Yochanan: What is the meaning of the saying of Rav: "Eight(1) vessels of the idols of Egypt, to what purpose? One vessel which was in the days of Moshe, and one vessel which was in the days of Pharaoh Nechoh, and one vessel which was dedicated to the utensils of her(2) own household! Notes: (1) The number "eight" is written in the original text in the form of the Hebrew numeral "shlishah" (שָׁלֹשׁ), which is an ordinal number indicating the quantity of the vessels. The translation maintains the ordinal number to preserve the original style and format of the Talmudic discourse. (2) The word "her" is a pronoun referring to the Egyptian idol, and is transliterated as "her" to preserve the original style and format of the Talmudic discourse.

Ammi of Nehardea, son of Papa, said: "If I, the Lord, have not made you, and you are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me; if I, the Lord, have not made you" — I have not made you to a people, and I have not made you to a nation. "You are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me" — we have said: "Cut off from them, cut off from them." I have not made you to a people, and I have not made you to a nation. "You are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me" — we have said: "Cut off from them, cut off from them." — for they are all cut off, and they are all cut off.

Rava bar Pappa, may we be inscribed in the Book of the Righteous for our deeds: "Rabbananu tzaddikim baShomerim na'ehu tehilah?" "Al tiqriyeh na'ehu tehilah", elai na'ehu tehilah, zeh mosheh v'david, shel lo shelto shelamim, shaltonu shonaim eihem b'maaseihem.

Rav — said: "The land of the Philistines is forbidden to him." — Mar: "From the time of the first rededication, when the Temple was desecrated, the altar was destroyed, the vessels were taken away, the priests were slain, the people were scattered, and the prince was exiled." — Rav: "What is the meaning of this? — My son said: Under the severity of the Sanhedrin's decrees, which are enacted in the Sanhedrin's hall."

Rabbis, teach: If one is forced to look at the face of a woman who is not worthy of him, to gaze upon the face of one who is worthy of him — it is not permitted, and to gaze upon the face of one who is in his hand — to take them from his hand. For all those who are forced to look at the face of a woman who is worthy of him — it is as if he is enticing his own children to look at her, and those who are in his hand — to take them from his hand. For all those who are forced to look at the face of a woman who is worthy of him — it is as if he is enticing his own children to look at her, and those who are in his hand — to take them from his hand.

And thus we have seen in the wickedness of the Kadmoni, that he has set his eyes on that which we are worthy of — that which he can provoke to anger, and that which he can take from us by his hand. Said R. Baruch ha-Levi: I have said: Let not the king sit upon all that is in them, and let him not live among them, for he is the most hated of all those who are among them, and the most hated of all living things.

I said: Walk in the wilderness, desolate, for upon his own flesh he walks. I said: He who is not able to fulfill his own desires, is not able to fulfill the desires of another, for he is like a donkey that is fed. He who says: "I will take a wife and I will take a wife," is speaking of himself and his own seed, for he is like a woman who is pregnant with herself and with her seed. He who says: "I will take a wife" is speaking of himself and his own seed, for he is like a woman who is pregnant with herself and with her seed.

Abshalom hath not been put to shame in his heart — to thee hath he not been put to shame. For if his father had not been upon a hundred and twenty pilgashim — to thee hath he not been put to shame. As it is said: "When they saw the men, they took counsel together, and said: 'Let us now make a covenant with them, that we may be at peace with them.'" — For the sake of that which his father had upon a hundred and twenty pilgashim: to thee hath he not been put to shame. For if he had been put to shame in the leib of his father, and in the leib of the house of din, and in the leib of Israel — as it is said: "He hath put to shame the leib of men of Israel" — to thee hath he not been put to shame. For the sake of that which he hath put to shame the leib of men of Israel — to thee hath he not been put to shame. Seventy cubits. As it is said: "He hath taken seventy cubits in his hand, and hath put them to shame."

And thus to explain the good: from Miriam, the daughter of Hittite, to Mosheh, the sinner, one and the same, as it is said: "And you shall stand against the sinners of your brother, and you shall not let them live." — to you, O Israel, a law of days in the Torah, which says: "And the people did not sin against the Lord, until the provocation of Miriam.".

Moshe took the tablets of the covenant from him, and there was no one in Israel greater than him, as it is said: "And he took the tablets of the covenant from him" — from whom was he greater than Moshe who had not been seduced by him in the places, as it is said: "And he buried him in the cave." For it is not for Moshe by his own power, as they say, that he would be for all the righteous, as it is said: "And he will lead you to your face, to correct you, as the Lord your God commanded you."

Gemara: Shmushon in his eyes is marad, as it is said: "And he said to his father or his mother, take for me, for I have done righteousness in his eyes" — to you, let us take the garments of his eyes, as it is said: "And they took hold of him and bound his eyes".

Who is he? And they say: "He who has no father or mother, let him not be put to death, for it is written: 'The soul of the wicked one is hated of the Most High, and he shall not be destroyed.'" For if his father and mother did not know him — in the book of his righteousness he was not written.

Behold, the deceit of the wicked, for he has revealed to him the entirety of his heart. Say, is it not known? Said Rabbi Chanina, said Rabbi Rab: One should beware of the words of truth. Said Abaye: Know him in his own words, in his own deeds, the righteous one who removes the weights from the scales of justice. For when he says, "I am a stranger to God," he says, "The staff and the rod shall be no more." Said the sages: The staff and the rod are not to be used, for he has said.

And it was, when He was righteous in His words, all the days, and He was hated. What is the meaning of "He was hated"? Said Rabbi Yitzchak: The words of the wicked are like a sword, piercing from beneath, from the depths of His throne.

Rabbis, beware! Do not eat wine, and do not drink, and do not eat, and do not drink. What is the meaning of "all the evil"? And to that: until the time of the words of the prophets that are still in the wilderness?! Said Rabbi Yitzchak: The words that are forbidden in the decree of the princes.

Rav Yitzchak said: The one who has taken upon himself the yoke of the Torah, let him be like a man who has taken upon himself the yoke of a beast — to be careful with his words, lest he be liable for the sin of speaking in vain.

sentences.text: פָּנֶיהָ מוֹרִיקוֹת. הִיא כָּחֲלָה לוֹ עֵינֶיהָ — לְפִיכָךְ עֵינֶיהָ בּוֹלְטוֹת. הִיא קָלְעָה לוֹ אֶת שְׂעָרָהּ — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן סוֹתֵר אֶת שְׂעָרָהּ. הִיא הֶרְאֲתָה לוֹ בְּאֶצְבַּע — לְפִיכָךְ צִיפּוֹרְנֶיהָ נוֹשְׁרוֹת. הִיא חָגְרָה לוֹ בְּצִילְצוֹל — לְפִיכָךְ כֹּהֵן מֵבִיא חֶבֶל הַמִּצְרִי וְקוֹשֵׁר לָהּ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ. הִיא פָּשְׁטָה לוֹ אֶת יְרֵיכָהּ — לְפִיכָךְ יְרֵיכָהּ נוֹפֶלֶת.

sentences.text: אִינִי? וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: שָׁלֹשׁ(ה) כּוֹסוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בְּמִצְרַיִם, לָמָּה? אַחַת שֶׁשָּׁתָת בִּימֵי מֹשֶׁה, וְאַחַת שֶׁשָּׁתָת בִּימֵי פַּרְעֹה נְכֹה, וְאַחַת שֶׁעֲתִידָה לִשְׁתּוֹת עִם חַבְרוֹתֶיהָ!
sentences.human_translation: Is that so? But didn’t Rava say: Why three cups that are stated with regard to Egypt One that it drank in the days of Moses one that it drank in the days of Pharaoh Neco, and one that it will drink in the future with its companions,
sentences.llm_translation: R. Yochanan: What is the meaning of the saying of Rav: "Eight(1) vessels of the idols of Egypt, to what purpose? One vessel which was in the days of Moshe, and one vessel which was in the days of Pharaoh Nechoh, and one vessel which was dedicated to the utensils of her(2) own household! Notes: (1) The number "eight" is written in the original text in the form of the Hebrew numeral "shlishah" (שָׁלֹשׁ), which is an ordinal number indicating the quantity of the vessels. The translation maintains the ordinal number to preserve the original style and format of the Talmudic discourse. (2) The word "her" is a pronoun referring to the Egyptian idol, and is transliterated as "her" to preserve the original style and format of the Talmudic discourse.

sentences.text: אַמֵּימָר מַתְנֵי לְהָא דְּרַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא אַהָא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי אֲנִי ה׳ לֹא שָׁנִיתִי וְאַתֶּם בְּנֵי יַעֲקֹב לֹא כְלִיתֶם״? ״אֲנִי ה׳ לֹא שָׁנִיתִי״ — לֹא הִכֵּיתִי לְאוּמָּהּ וְשָׁנִיתִי לָהּ. ״וְאַתֶּם בְּנֵי יַעֲקֹב לֹא כְלִיתֶם״ — הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״חִצַּי אֲכַלֶּה בָּם״. חִצַּי כָּלִין, וְהֵן אֵינָן כָּלִין.
sentences.human_translation: Ameimar teaches that of Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa with regard to this: What is which is written: “For I the Lord change not; and you, sons of Jacob, are not consumed” “For I the Lord change [ shaniti ] not” I did not strike a nation and repeat [ shaniti ] it, “And you, sons of Jacob, are not consumed,” This is as that which is written: I will consume My arrows upon them” My arrows are consumed and they, are not consumed
sentences.llm_translation: Ammi of Nehardea, son of Papa, said: "If I, the Lord, have not made you, and you are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me; if I, the Lord, have not made you" — I have not made you to a people, and I have not made you to a nation. "You are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me" — we have said: "Cut off from them, cut off from them." I have not made you to a people, and I have not made you to a nation. "You are the sons of Jacob, not like unto me" — we have said: "Cut off from them, cut off from them." — for they are all cut off, and they are all cut off.

sentences.text: אָמַר רַב הַמְנוּנָא: אֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא נִפְרָע מִן הָאָדָם עַד שֶׁתִּתְמַלֵּא סְאָתוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בִּמְלֹאות שִׂפְקוֹ יֵצֶר לוֹ וְגוֹ׳״.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Hamnuna says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not punish a person until his se’a , is filled, as it is stated: “In the fullness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits;
sentences.llm_translation: Rava said: There is no one who is not guilty of the sin of Adam, from the moment he was created until the moment he is put to death, as it is said: "The heart is prone to evil from the time it is formed in the womb, and so on." sentences.text: דָּרֵשׁ רַב חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״רַנְּנוּ צַדִּיקִים בַּה׳ לַיְשָׁרִים נָאוָה תְהִלָּה״? אַל תִּקְרֵי ״נָאוָה תְהִלָּה״, אֶלָּא ״נָוֶה תְהִלָּה״, זֶה מֹשֶׁה וְדָוִד, שֶׁלֹּא שָׁלְטוּ שׂוֹנְאֵיהֶם בְּמַעֲשֵׂיהֶם.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa interpreted homiletically: What is which is written: “Rejoice in the Lord, you righteous, praise is comely for the upright [ nava tehilla ]” Do not read Praise is comely [ nava ]; rather, A house [ naveh ] of praise. This Moses and David, whose enemies did not rule over their achievements,
sentences.llm_translation: Rava bar Pappa, may we be inscribed in the Book of the Righteous for our deeds: "Rabbananu tzaddikim baShomerim na'ehu tehilah?" "Al tiqriyeh na'ehu tehilah", elai na'ehu tehilah, zeh mosheh v'david, shel lo shelto shelamim, shaltonu shonaim eihem b'maaseihem.

sentences.text: דָּוִד — דִּכְתִיב: ״טָבְעוּ בָאָרֶץ שְׁעָרֶיהָ״. מֹשֶׁה — דְּאָמַר מָר: מִשֶּׁנִּבְנָה מִקְדָּשׁ רִאשׁוֹן נִגְנַז אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד, קְרָשָׁיו קְרָסָיו וּבְרִיחָיו וְעַמּוּדָיו וַאֲדָנָיו. הֵיכָא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר אֲבִימִי: תַּחַת מְחִילּוֹת שֶׁל הֵיכָל.
sentences.human_translation: David, as it is written: “Her gates are sunk into the ground” Moses, as the Master said: When the first Temple was built, the Tent of Meeting was sequestered, its boards, its clasps, and its bars, and its pillars, and its sockets. Where Rav Ḥisda says Avimi says: Beneath the tunnels of the Sanctuary.
sentences.llm_translation: Rav — said: "The land of the Philistines is forbidden to him." — Mar: "From the time of the first rededication, when the Temple was desecrated, the altar was destroyed, the vessels were taken away, the priests were slain, the people were scattered, and the prince was exiled." — Rav: "What is the meaning of this? — My son said: Under the severity of the Sanhedrin's decrees, which are enacted in the Sanhedrin's hall."

sentences.text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: סוֹטָה נָתְנָה עֵינֶיהָ בְּמִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לָהּ, מַה שֶּׁבִּיקְּשָׁה — לֹא נִיתַּן לָהּ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדָהּ — נְטָלוּהוּ מִמֶּנָּה. שֶׁכׇּל הַנּוֹתֵן עֵינָיו בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ שֶׁלּוֹ — מַה שֶּׁמְבַקֵּשׁ אֵין נוֹתְנִין לוֹ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדוֹ — נוֹטְלִין הֵימֶנּוּ.
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught sota placed her eyes, on one who is unfit for her, That which she desired, is not given to her, And that which she had, was taken away from her, that anyone who places his eyes on that which is not his is not given what he desires, and that which he had is taken from him.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbis, teach: If one is forced to look at the face of a woman who is not worthy of him, to gaze upon the face of one who is worthy of him — it is not permitted, and to gaze upon the face of one who is in his hand — to take them from his hand. For all those who are forced to look at the face of a woman who is worthy of him — it is as if he is enticing his own children to look at her, and those who are in his hand — to take them from his hand. For all those who are forced to look at the face of a woman who is worthy of him — it is as if he is enticing his own children to look at her, and those who are in his hand — to take them from his hand.

sentences.text: וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בְּנָחָשׁ הַקַּדְמוֹנִי, שֶׁנָּתַן עֵינָיו בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לוֹ — מַה שֶּׁבִּיקֵּשׁ לֹא נָתְנוּ לוֹ, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדוֹ נְטָלוּהוּ מִמֶּנּוּ. אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהֵא מֶלֶךְ עַל כׇּל בְּהֵמָה וְחַיָּה, וְעַכְשָׁיו ״אָרוּר הוּא מִכׇּל הַבְּהֵמָה וּמִכֹּל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה״.
sentences.human_translation: And, so too, we found with regard to the primeval snake for he placed his eyes on that which was unfit for him, that which he desired was not given to him, and that which was in his possession was taken from him. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: I said will be king over every domesticated animal and non-domesticated animal, but now he is cursed more than all the domesticated animals and all the non-domesticated animals of the field,
sentences.llm_translation: And thus we have seen in the wickedness of the Kadmoni, that he has set his eyes on that which we are worthy of — that which he can provoke to anger, and that which he can take from us by his hand. Said R. Baruch ha-Levi: I have said: Let not the king sit upon all that is in them, and let him not live among them, for he is the most hated of all those who are among them, and the most hated of all living things.

sentences.text: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהַלֵּךְ בְּקוֹמָה זְקוּפָה, עַכְשָׁיו — ״עַל גְּחוֹנוֹ יֵלֵךְ״. אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי יְהֵא מַאֲכָלוֹ מַאֲכַל אָדָם, עַכְשָׁיו — ״עָפָר יֹאכַל״. הוּא אָמַר אֶהֱרוֹג אֶת אָדָם וְאֶשָּׂא אֶת חַוָּה, עַכְשָׁיו — ״אֵיבָה אָשִׁית בֵּינְךָ וּבֵין הָאִשָּׁה וּבֵין זַרְעֲךָ וּבֵין זַרְעָהּ״.
sentences.human_translation: I said will walk upright, now he shall go on his belly; I said his food will be food a person, now he shall eat dust. said: I will kill Adam and marry Eve, now: “I will put enmity between you and the woman and between your seed and her seed”
sentences.llm_translation: I said: Walk in the wilderness, desolate, for upon his own flesh he walks. I said: He who is not able to fulfill his own desires, is not able to fulfill the desires of another, for he is like a donkey that is fed. He who says: "I will take a wife and I will take a wife," is speaking of himself and his own seed, for he is like a woman who is pregnant with herself and with her seed. He who says: "I will take a wife" is speaking of himself and his own seed, for he is like a woman who is pregnant with herself and with her seed.

sentences.text: וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בְּקַיִן וְקֹרַח וּבִלְעָם וְדוֹאֵג וַאֲחִיתוֹפֶל וְגֵחֲזִי וְאַבְשָׁלוֹם וַאֲדוֹנִיָּהוּ וְעוּזִּיָּהוּ וְהָמָן — שֶׁנָּתְנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם בְּמַה שֶּׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לָהֶם. מַה שֶּׁבִּיקְּשׁוּ — לֹא נִיתַּן לָהֶם, וּמַה שֶּׁבְּיָדָם — נְטָלוּהוּ מֵהֶם.
sentences.human_translation: And so we found with regard to Cain, and Korah, and Balaam, and Doeg, and Ahithophel, and Gehazi, and Absalom, and Adonijah, and Uzziah, and Haman, who placed their eyes on that which is unfit for them, and what they desired was not given to them, and what they had was taken from them.
sentences.llm_translation: And thus we have seen in the manner of their i.e. the nations inquiry and their i.e. the nations inquiry and their i.e. the nations inquiry and their i.e. the nations inquiry and their i.e. the nations inquiry and their i.e. the nations inquiry — that they i.e. the nations are not worthy of our i.e. the nations inquiry — what i.e. the nations has provoked them — let us not i.e. the nations provoke them, and what i.e. the nations has provoked them — let us i.e. the nations provoke them.

sentences.text: בַּיָּרֵךְ הִתְחִילָּה בַּעֲבֵירָה וְכוּ׳. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּתֵת ה׳ אֶת יְרֵכֵךְ נוֹפֶלֶת וְאֶת בִּטְנֵךְ צָבָה״ — וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְצָבְתָה בִטְנָהּ וְנָפְלָה יְרֵכָהּ״?
sentences.human_translation: She began her transgression with thigh From where are these matters If we say because it is written when the Lord does make your thigh to fall away, and your belly to swell” but isn’t written “And her belly shall swell, and her thigh shall fall away”

sentences.text: אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּי לָיֵיט — לָיֵיט תְּחִילָּה יָרֵךְ, וַהֲדַר בֶּטֶן לָיֵיט, וּמַיָּא כִּי בָּדְקִי — כִּי אוֹרְחַיְיהוּ בָּדְקִי, בֶּטֶן בְּרֵישָׁא וַהֲדַר יָרֵךְ. בִּקְלָלָה נָמֵי כְּתִיב: ״לַצְבּוֹת בֶּטֶן וְלַנְפִּל יָרֵךְ״! הָהוּא דְּמוֹדַע לַהּ כֹּהֵן דְּבֶטֶן בְּרֵישָׁא וַהֲדַר יָרֵךְ, שֶׁלֹּא לְהוֹצִיא לַעַז עַל מַיִם הַמָּרִים.
sentences.human_translation: Abaye said When curses he first curses the thigh and then he curses the stomach, but when the water evaluates it evaluates along its way first stomach and then thigh. in curse it is also written: and will cause your belly to swell, and your thigh to fall away” That that the priest notifies her that stomach first and then thigh, so that not cast aspersions on the bitter water.

sentences.human_translation: Samson followed his eyes, therefore the Philistines gouged out his eyes, as it is stated: “And the Philistines laid hold on him, and put out his eyes”
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Menachem said: If one is walking behind someone and his eyes are fixed on him — to draw him out of his path, one should take away his gaze, as it is said: "They have grasped the pelt of the blind, and they have torn it."
